# Calculus of variation

::: {.definition name="Calculus of variation"}
Suppose $M$ is a manifold, and $L: TM \to \mathbb R$ is a smooth functional. A
curve $\gamma: \mathbb R \to M$ is said to be a critical point of calculus of
variations if in local coordinates $(U, q, \dot q)$,
$$
\frac{d}{dt} \left ( \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot q} \circ \gamma_* \right) -
\frac{\partial L}{\partial q} \circ \gamma_* = 0
$$
where
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial L}{\partial q} &= \left ( \frac{\partial L}{\partial q^1}, \quad \dots, \quad \frac{\partial L}{\partial q^n} \right ) \\
\gamma_* &= (\gamma, \gamma')
\end{aligned}
$$
:::
